content: kfb *sl1 wyif k1 sl1 wyib k1 repeat from * to the last 3 sts sl1 wyif k2tog row 2 - ws - sl1 wyif p2 *sl1 wyif p3 repeat from * to the last stitch sl1 wyif row 3 mc - rs - kfb *k3 sl1 wyib repeat from * to last 3 sts k1 k2tog row 4 - ws - sl1 wyif purl to the last stitch sl1 wyif keep repeating row 1-4 always bringing the new yarn up from underneath to keep the edge neat and tidy until you have the length you want stopping after a row 2 for a single loop at least 51cm/20 in length needs to fit over the head for a double loop approx 130cm/51 in length block lightly i would recommend blocking before joining in case your strip changes size significantly and you want to make adjustments see next page for joining info just weave it by susan ashcroft for personal non-commercial use only 2 joining the 2 ends of the strip stop after a row 2 and then remove the waste yarn from the provisional cast-on placing the stitches on 2nd needle or the opposite end of a circular needle as you remove the waste yarn on the right in the photo the purl bumps will disappear and you will be left with knit and slipped stitches in the mc yarn be sure to line everything up before starting to seam the slipped mc stitch should be lined up with the middle stitch of the 3 cc stitches on the other needle be sure to allow for the shift at the edges caused by working on the bias 2 sts into 1 on one side 1 stich into 2 on the opposite side you may like to baste your work to keep everything in place while you seam kitchener/graft the 2 ends together the seam will be almost invisible just weave it by susan ashcroft for personal non-commercial use only 3
